animalOfTheDay.name: woodpecker
facts: Acorn woodpeckers drill thousands of holes to store acorns – 'granary trees'.
Their tongues wrap around skulls to cushion brains during pecking.
Woodpeckers have shock-absorbing skulls and compressible brain cases.
Pileated woodpeckers create rectangular holes in trees searching for ants.

calendar.name: warthog
facts: Birds like mongooses remove ticks from warthogs during grooming sessions.
Warthogs have facial 'warts' that protect eyes during fights.
They reverse into burrows – tusks facing outward to deter predators.
Warthogs kneel on calloused wrists to graze low vegetation.

calendar.name: wasp
facts: Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.

calendar.name: water buffalo
facts: Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.
Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.
Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.

calendar.name: wild boar
facts: Wild boars have razor-sharp tusks that regrow continuously.
They create 'boar baths' – mud wallows that cool and remove parasites.
Boars run 30 mph and jump 5-ft fences.
Sows build 'farrowing nests' of woven grass before giving birth.

calendar.name: wild dog
facts: African wild dogs vote to hunt via sneezing – more sneezes trigger departures.
They regurgitate food for pups, elders, and injured pack members.
Packs hold territories up to 900 square miles.
Wild dogs have mottled coats unique to each individual.

calendar.name: wombat
facts: Wombats produce cube-shaped feces – unique among animals – to prevent rolling.
They dig complex burrows with multiple entrances and sleeping chambers.
They can run 25 mph despite stubby legs.
Wombat rear hides have cartilage plates – blocking dingo bites when fleeing to tunnels.

calendar.name: woodpecker
facts: Woodpeckers have shock-absorbing skulls and compressible brain cases.
Acorn woodpeckers drill thousands of holes to store acorns – 'granary trees'.
Pileated woodpeckers create rectangular holes in trees searching for ants.
Their tongues wrap around skulls to cushion brains during pecking.

randomAnimals.name: dolphin
facts: Dolphins have names for each other and can call specific individuals.
They use echolocation so precisely they can detect objects buried in sand.
They can recognize themselves in mirrors, showing self-awareness.
Dolphins sleep with one brain hemisphere at a time to stay alert for breathing.

randomAnimals.name: nene
facts: They are highly endangered, but breeding programs have helped increase their population.
They feed mainly on grasses, leaves, and berries.
They evolved to live in volcanic areas, and their legs are less adapted for swimming than other geese, but better for walking on uneven terrain.
The Nene, also known as the Hawaiian goose, is the only goose species found in Hawaii and is the state bird.

randomAnimals.name: cobra
facts: Cobras can 'stand up' by raising up to one-third of their body length.
Despite their reputation, they prefer to avoid confrontation with humans.
King cobras are the longest venomous snakes in the world.
They spread their hood as a warning display when threatened.
